reviewText:
I thought about starting this review countering all those negative reviews talking about money, controller support and the ****......but it is not fair. I'll start talking about this fantastic old game....which not every mind can evidently sustain.

This is a labirinth game. it is designed to make you lose your way, confuse and upset you. As every labirinth ever constructed (and deserving the name) every corridor appears the same with few changings (mostly traps).
This is the goal of the game....NOT LETTING YOU OUT! so why should it help you?
No, you're going to try and navigate this infinite dedalus, dodging traps and collecting utilities along the way, until you can find the solution for the riddles behind every door you'll find (or die trying, which is funny in itself! never laughed as much with any other game over).
Naturally is an old game, and pixels dominates everything....wait, what are you saying? 2014 was the year of pixel art? how STRANGE. (graphics = useless) at least for this game type, go take a look (and play) Papers
date: please" for instance: pixel art at it's best
hoursPlayed: fun and challenging. Only difference with Litil Divil

reviewText: ok guys i know this game is old and runs off an dos box emulator, but from all the reviews i have read im gonna try n help out make things a bit easier for this classic, its not revamped it is literally the 1993 release of this game made for dos back in the 90's the game is challenging, hard and annoying at times but the age old question is? whats the dam keys? well i downlaoded the original manual and found that the 2,4,6,8, on the numpad are the keys for walking around, and the action keys are x and z, i have personally tested this and it does infact work fine, there's NO issues with keys, they respond first time everytime. as for controller support? now u know the keys? use xpadder to map them and wha laa, a controller supported old school game :) peace all and enjoy.

reviewText:
Litil Divil is and old school adventure in a labyrinth game, which takes place in the Underworld.

You’re Mutt a little devil, who goes to the deeps in search of a pizza? I've played games from 1962 to modern games, but sadly, I couldn't really enjoy this title. Overall, I felt, the controls were very clunky, it doesn't give you any kind of information at all, except for the intro video (Not even what the controls are). While I understand this game is obviously old, my point is that, there are other games, I believe, you'd enjoy more than this one, and not because it's old, but for the reasons previously mentioned.

★★☆☆☆ | Disliked it
voteText: 36 of 61 people (59%) found this review helpful 4 people found this review funny

reviewText: I bought this immediately because I used to own a copy back in the 90's and loved this game back then. Although the animations/framerate may be considered less than ideal by modern standards, I find that it has aged reasonably well. It's a nice little old-school blend of various puzzle/action/platform minigames tied together by increasingly complicated trap-filled labyrinth levels. The game has a lot of humor and charm, while being reasonably difficult (whether it's for the right reasons or not is debatable. You won't regret having a pencil and grap paper available though.)

reviewText:
A well made labyrinth game. I Remember seeing my neighbor playing this game in 1999 (Game was released 1993)! The game is a huge challenge. The entire game you will be running in this maze collecting utilities along the way and dodging traps. Objective to the game is to retrieve the Mystical Pizza of Plenty, but you must find out the riddles to all of the doors which makes this game hard. Each riddle will be fustrating and you will end up dieing and dieing but thats what makes the game challenging. Each room has a unique level/puzzle feel. Game can be beatin anywhere from 3 hours to 15hours.

Pros
Challenging game
More than 40 rooms
when afk you day dream (funny)
Animations are pretty good for its time


Cons
Controls you must figure out yourself
No controller support

reviewText:
It's just... bad.  I grew up in the age of DOS games, and I wouldn't have played this as a child, either.  After ragequitting twice, I discovered the following:

Direction controls: Arrow keys or 2,4,6,8 on the numeric keypad.
Fire buttons: Z and X.

It fails to mention that you need to press the direction you want to attack, to attack, but with the poor controls aside, the playability is low.  The labyrinth is hard to navigate and the visibility of traps is poor.  There may be a lot of nostalgia for people with this game... but I'll never play it again.

reviewText:
The only thing I can concretely say is that Litil Divil is some form of dungeon crawler. The game was clearly emulated from an older time so I’m sure the full color manual that was sold with the original game really filled in the blanks, but as a standalone title it feels like all there are are blanks.

It took me almost 2 minutes to figure out how to get the game to begin once I was at the start screen. I still am not entirely sure which key actually did it. Once dropped into the game I quickly figured out the arrow keys move.. easy enough. I walked 3 steps forward to be assaulted by a troll. Okay back up and figure out how to attack. I proceeded to press every key on the keyboard to no avail. Another 4 or 5 minutes later I realize that you actually have to press right, while against an enemy and then press the ‘X’ key. I don’t think it could have been more unintuitive. Regardless I pressed onwards to be dropped into a old school type dungeon crawler, a revelation that had me rather excited. After figuring out how to enter rooms (forward and ‘Z’ clearly, because thats the obvious go-to for object interaction) I poked my head into a few and each time was presented with a wild scene with no clear objective and no idea how to interact with the world to even be able to begin some trial and error.

Deep down I believe that Litil Divil may be a fun little game, but it’s torn down by the fact that digital delivery platforms don’t account for the original way to introduce players to a game world: manuals. Good Old Games does an awesome job of this by providing PDF downloads of said manuals. If Steam wants to keep pushing out ports of old DOS era titles (which it absolutely should) there needs to be a system in place for users to have clear and easy access to the media that was expected to be provided along with the game itself.

reviewText:
Both ENGLISH and ITALIAN review...

ITALIANO

Non so' cos'è sta roba... A quanto pare però è vecchio (anni 90') e gira su un emulatore, il che fa' già capire che non vale ASSOLUTAMENTE 9€.
La ditta avrà già fatto profitto quando aveva rilasciato sto gioco, non vedo perchè riproporlo a pagamento.
Non c'ho capito nulla, nessun menù iniziale, tasti strani (anche se usuali per l'epoca) e nulla di nulla.
Sinceramente certi giochi dovrebbero essere gratuiti.
Eppure l'idea sembrava buona, sembra un gioco simpatico.

4/10

ENGLISH

I don't know what this thing is... I know it's old (90 years) and run on a emulator, and that is usefull to understand that this game SHOULDN'T be sold on Steam for 9€.
The game's developers have released the game so many years ago, and I think they've already taken profit from the time they released.
Is confusing, no menu, no tutorial, strange keys (i know they may were normal at the time)...
These type of game should be FREE.
But the idea of the games seems good... But is unplayable.

4/10

reviewText: Boo!  This was a fav of mine back in the Amiga days so why release a classic in less than its original state?  I can let the graphics not being updated but the controller support...  well...  It sucks.  I think I saw mention from another reviewer on this issue.  Sure I could use the keyboard but I want to use my controller just like I did when I played it all those years ago.  The problem is I am running a Windows 7 system and whoever released this did so by using the floppy disc PC version released after the Amiga version and use DOSBOX emulator to try and pull this off with minimal effort on their part.  I feel like the Amiga CD32 version had some issues but I played it pretty far using a controller.  I then bought the PC version a few years later.  Then this is released on Steam and by now everything must be working if not improved because decades have passed.  Not.   Would have loved to say thumbs up and worth the memory.  Nice try.   I just think its clear that the fans would be the first do come and check it out and...  Well...  It is what it is.

reviewText:
This game is incredibly like Hell.

I went through a ridiculous dungeon, trudged through it all at an excruciatingly draggish pace, and faced off the final boss, which turned out to be a hefty fee at a toll. I literally had to give all the money I had to get through, and more! Then, when I got through, the final task was to give up the three really random items I picked up (a flashlight, an anvil, and a big gem) to get past 3 statues which I assume might have killed me if I didn't have them with me.

I experienced an incredible wave of relief getting past it all.
Then Level 2 began....

This wasn't the worst part of my gameplay. The absolute worst was navigating through the wordless interface of the Menu screen. What I thought was the icon for saving (it had the diskette icon on it, everyone knows that means save, right?!) was actually the Load icon. I ended up back in the first dungeon right after the toll. And for some reason all my items were gone, which meant I needed to go back through the entire dungeon to find them again. I spent an hour today on this, and I would say that I've spent an hour too long on this.

And yet, I would recommend this game, if only to keep the review score within the status quo, so that any poor, hapless soul who doesn't read the reviews might buy this merely because the scores were okay. Because I would like to think that one day in the future, when I look back at this game, I can say that some poor, hapless soul suffered as much as I did. And that will put me at ease.

reviewText: I grew up playing Dangerous Dave and Prince of Persia on my 286/386 so i'm not averse to old games with platform elements, but this is just not a good game. I doubt i would've enjoyed it even back then.

reviewText: Ok, despite the fact that I have absolutely NO idea what I'm doing in this game, and despite having to muddle around and find the right keys every time I play (I have a ♥♥♥♥ memory for some things) I have to say it's a fun game if you can look past the aged nature of it. Seriously, it's a good game and well worth a try, especially when you consider that you can often find it free somewhere. In fact, as of this writing, it IS free somewhere...maybe Indiegala?\n\nAnyway, it's infinitely better than Uriel's Chasm so what would it hurt?

reviewText:
When Publishers Just Want A Quick Buck...I like the believe that at this point in time game Developers and Publishers just... get the gaming Community and Market. Not that there is a whole lot to get, but mostly in this day and age Developers need to give each one of their titles the respect they deserve... when asking ten whole dollars up front.

Litil Divil, has been neglected, and it shows in the response that the community has had on Steam toward this game. It's beyond rough,  it is sad.

Pros  Nice classic animations and sounds
Moderately stable build of DOSBox, Alt+Tabbing out of game works properly
Multiple gameplay elements all strewn together that function properly, even if they lack explanation
Cons  The introduction movie was not included in the game
There is a lack of menus in game unless you wish to Save (Which resets current progress and gold in the area, and only keeps your map data) or Exit.
Higher resolution options are absent, unlike other Gremlin Games released for DOS which have added resolution options
The game manual that can be accessed through the Library tab in Steam is short, skimpy, and lacks detailed information about major aspects of the game (Such as the shop, object descriptions, and hints)

At a $10 price point you are asking a lot for a game that runs through a DOS Emulator, not that DOSBox is a terrible emulator, but it just goes to show how much they are asking for a product that hasn't been touched or altered one bit since its initial release. Gremlin Interactive was a group of very talented individuals who understood how to cram so much personality into a game it was astounding, but so see KISS/Funbox Ltd. simply throw this ancient game onto Steam and ask full price without updating it or giving any support is unacceptable.

Its a shame, really. I am a big fan of Realms of the Haunting (Another game by Gremlin), even though it was the community who released updated controls to make it fully playable on all systems. This game, is asking WAY TOO MUCH for WAY TOO LITTLE .

I wont trash on the bad gameplay because its obvious through other reviews how dated it is, but my real complaints mainly deal with the asking price compared to product worth.

0/10  IF the asking price for this was around 99cents, I can understand a bit of justification of the price. I recieved this game for free online, as most people did. I would have NEVER paid anything over 99 cents for this game. Period.
